column3: Economic consumption measures the expenditure of private households. It is gross domestic product minus government expenditures, investments, and exports. It is measured in 2005 international-dollars. This means it is adjusted for inflation and cross-country price differences.

column3: Fluorinated gases (‘F-gases’) are greenhouse gases used in industrial applications such as refrigerants, aerosols and white goods.

column3: Sulfur dioxide (SO₂) is an air pollutant produced as a by-product when fuels that contain sulfur are burned. It is often produced from the burning of coal.
column11: Riahi et al. (2017). The Shared Socioeconomic Pathways and their energy, land use, and greenhouse gas emissions implications: An overview, Global Environmental Change

column3: Black carbon is an air pollutant produced through the incomplete combustion of fossil fuels, biofuel, and biomass.
column11: Riahi et al. (2017). The Shared Socioeconomic Pathways and their energy, land use, and greenhouse gas emissions implications: An overview, Global Environmental Change

column3: Nitrous oxides (NOx) are local air pollutants produced when fuel is burned at high temperatures. NOx is often emitted by road vehicles, and industrial sources such as power plants.
column11: Riahi et al. (2017). The Shared Socioeconomic Pathways and their energy, land use, and greenhouse gas emissions implications: An overview, Global Environmental Change

column3: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are local air pollutants which are emitted from certain organic compounds which are present in fuels, as well as chemicals used in paints, varnishes and cleaning products.
column11: Riahi et al. (2017). The Shared Socioeconomic Pathways and their energy, land use, and greenhouse gas emissions implications: An overview, Global Environmental Change

column3: This assumes a global carbon price on carbon, measured in 2005 US$ per tonne of CO₂. This means prices are adjusted for inflation.

column3: Final energy is the energy delivered to consumers for end consumption e.g. household electricity, or petrol sold at the pump. It is primary energy energy minus losses which occur in the transformation of fuels into usable energy products (giving us 'secondary energy') minus transmission and distribution losses of getting electricity or heat to the end user.
column11: Riahi et al. (2017). The Shared Socioeconomic Pathways and their energy, land use, and greenhouse gas emissions implications: An overview, Global Environmental Change

column3: Primary energy is the energy embodied in natural resources prior to transformation into useful end products. For example, the energy stored in coal or oil before combustion in a power plant. The transformation of fossil fuels into their secondary form (such as electricity) results in large inefficiencies due to heat loss. This means primary energy is higher than the energy used by a population.
column11: Riahi et al. (2017). The Shared Socioeconomic Pathways and their energy, land use, and greenhouse gas emissions implications: An overview, Global Environmental Change

column3: Primary energy is the energy embodied in natural resources prior to transformation into useful end products. For example, the energy stored in coal or oil before combustion in a power plant. The transformation of fossil fuels into their secondary form (such as electricity) results in large inefficiencies due to heat loss. This means primary energy is higher than the energy used by a population.

column3: Final energy is the energy delivered to consumers for end consumption e.g. household electricity, or petrol sold at the pump. column3: Primary energy is the energy embodied in natural resources prior to transformation into useful end products. For example, the energy stored in coal or oil before combustion in a power plant. The transformation of fossil fuels into their secondary form (such as electricity) results in large inefficiencies due to heat loss. This means primary energy is higher than the energy used by a population.

column3: Primary energy is the energy embodied in natural resources prior to transformation into useful end products. For example, the energy stored in coal or oil before combustion in a power plant. The transformation of fossil fuels into their secondary form (such as electricity) results in large inefficiencies due to heat loss. This means primary energy is higher than the energy used by a population.

The transformation of fossil fuels into their secondary form (such as electricity) results in large inefficiencies due to heat loss. This means primary energy is higher than the energy used by a population.
column11: Riahi et al. (2017). The Shared Socioeconomic Pathways and their energy, land use, and greenhouse gas emissions implications: An overview, Global Environmental Change
column13: Primary, secondary, final, useful: What are the four ways of measuring energy?

It is primary energy minus energy losses that have occurred in the transformation or raw fuels (such as coal or gas) into electricity, heat or liquid transport fuels.

column3: Primary energy is the energy embodied in natural resources prior to transformation into useful end products. For example, the energy stored in coal or oil before combustion in a power plant. The transformation of fossil fuels into their secondary form (such as electricity) results in large inefficiencies due to heat loss. This means primary energy is higher than the energy used by a population.

column3: Primary energy is the energy embodied in natural resources prior to transformation into useful end products. For example, the energy stored in coal or oil before combustion in a power plant. The transformation of fossil fuels into their secondary form (such as electricity) results in large inefficiencies due to heat loss. This means primary energy is higher than the energy used by a population.
